clusters.description: The paper’s baseline/conditional distribution (“no serious de dicto optimization pressure”) is underspecified, unstable, or incoherent; changing what counts as default coordination/learning/optimization (or noting survival already implies coordination) could flip the conclusion.

The 99.99th-percentile / “best feasible future” benchmark is distribution-relative and tail-sensitive, so the ‘mostly-great’ threshold can become hard by construction (or depends on epistemic/moral choices) rather than reflecting a substantive claim about reality.

The multiplicative ‘product of many factors’ model (and its independence/near-zero assumptions) is unjustified; with correlation, floors, substitutability, or additive/threshold aggregation, the ‘needle-threading’/‘one flaw ruins everything’ conclusion weakens or collapses.

Appeals to moral disagreement (‘many perspectives call the present a catastrophe’) don’t justify large expected value loss; disagreement may just mean someone objects, and without a principled aggregation it doesn’t imply fragility or ‘most value lost.’

The paper’s fat-tail/value-efficiency argument is a weak analogy or misapplied: fat tails in wealth/citations don’t track moral value; advanced optimization/copying may flatten tails; and fat tails don’t imply a razor-thin near-optimal set (may be broad plateaus or even make big gains easier).

The taxonomy/framework for moral views is too narrow/coarse (forces theories into cardinal utility functional forms), so the ‘most plausible views are fussy’ result may be a modeling artifact; many hybrid/threshold/constraint/pluralist theories could be easygoing.

Intertheoretic comparison/normalization under moral uncertainty is doing the heavy lifting; different reasonable scaling/anchoring/decision rules flip the result, so moral uncertainty can’t robustly support ‘fussiness dominates.’

Population ethics/scale arguments are contested; treating non-expansion or ‘too few lives’ as massive value loss smuggles in totalist/pro-expansion assumptions, so this channel can’t bear much weight.

The ‘bounded views are effectively linear’ move depends on speculative cosmology/aliens/our marginal impact being tiny; if those empirical assumptions fail, bounded concave views may be genuinely easygoing.

The paper’s VNM/cardinal-comparability assumptions (completeness/independence/continuity) pre-filter toward fussiness; dropping them (lexical constraints, incomparability, satisficing) undermines the quantitative comparisons and the ‘fussy’ conclusion.

Narrowness in abstract outcome/value space doesn’t imply low probability or need for deliberate optimization: realistic dynamics may have attractors/convergent pressures/institutional learning that funnel probability mass into good regions by default.

Many alleged ‘single-flaw’ catastrophes may be preventable/correctable/endogenously stabilized by good institutions, meta-institutions, bargaining, or de re selection pressures; the paper underplays coupling/corrigibility and overstates irreversibility.

Digital-personhood/voting creates a sybil/adversarial ‘fake moral patient’ attack surface; the paper misses identity verification/manipulation dynamics that change the real crux of digital rights governance.

Institutionalizing ‘fussiness’/moral precaution creates governance pathologies (paralysis, veto capture, maximalism), so the thesis is self-defeating when applied: it becomes a power-amplifying rule rather than a neutral diagnosis.
